awd_titl_txt: RCN: Coordinating and Advancing Analytical Approaches for Policy Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Effective governance hinges on how individuals interpret and respond to public policies, which are comprised of carefully designed language that conveys who can do what, when, and how. Adequately understanding the link between the design of public policies and behavior requires two complementary advancements. First, scientists must promote intellectual exchange on the development of generalizable and reliable approaches for studying policy designs. Second, these same scientists must coordinate with others focused on assessing how behavior emerges in response to, or sometimes alongside, policy designs. In the former case, policy design scholars confront a trade-off between detailed small-sample case studies that capture nuance in particular contexts, and large-sample studies, which fail to pick up on nuance but generalize across policies and contexts. In the latter case, behavioral scientists confront a different set of challenges. Behavioral scientists have advanced understanding of how individuals interpret and respond to specific instructions embedded in policy designs, but offer few insights about behavioral responses to different combinations of instructions, or how policy design and behavior co-evolve. Exchanging insights with policy design scholars focused on characterizing the language of public policy allows behavioral scientists to effectively respond to such issues. This Research Coordination Network (RCN) initiates an interdisciplinary and international network of policy design scholars and behavioral scientists to harness and integrate their insights to better understand the interplay between policy design and behavior. In support of this objective, RCN participants share and coordinate scientific contributions relating to: (1) theoretical and methodological development of a broadly applicable approach for dissecting the content of public policies, called the Institutional Grammar (IG); (2) development of theoretically informed metrics for evaluating policy designs; and (3) assessments of actual and simulated behavior in policy governed settings. 

RCN contributions derive from three key focal areas around which the collaboration evolves: (1) IG-Extract: Development of methods on open source software to automatically extract rules from rich text (such as policy documents) and format them into an IG structured database; (2) IG-Analytics: Identification of theoretically-informed metrics for measuring policy designs and evaluating the quality of policies coded in accordance with the IG; and (3) IG-Behave: Exploration of how the IG can be leveraged to support game theoretic, agent based modeling, and large-n observational research, focusing specifically on how policy designs influence actual and simulated behavior, and how behavior evolves in relation to policies. Tools and techniques developed through the RCN are based on principles of Commons-Based Peer Production (CBPP), which emphasizes the use of collaborative platforms and innovative licensing for engaging scholars with common intellectual interests in scientific problem solving. As a package, the RCN contributes understanding regarding how institutional analysis, independently or coupled with behavioral assessments, can be used in the study of policy and governance. Ultimately, the RCN offers guidance for more effective governance in a wide array of policy domains. This guidance is valuable for policy designers responsible for constructing the language of public policies for successfully achieving policy objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Research Coordination Network: 

Coordinating and Advancing Analytical Approaches for Policy Design


The RCN convened an international and interdisciplinary team of scholars to study the relationship between policy design and behavior. The RCN focused on developing rigorous and reliable methods to study policy design as a basis for understanding this relationship. All policies are made up of carefully designed language that conveys who can do what, when, and how, and focal methodologies enable systematic assessment of policy language using computational and non-computational approaches. 

The RCN team advanced an approach to study policy content called the Institutional Grammar (IG), where “institutional” refers to rules, norms, and shared strategies that govern social systems. Examples of institutions pertinent to the RCN are public policies. The IG orients an analysis of institutions on two types of “institutional statements” (akin to policy provisions):  those regulating actions (regulative statements) and those defining systemic features  (constitutive statements). The IG identifies a set of components that are common to regulative and constitutive statements, each of which are associated with specific kinds of information found in them, such as the action(s) assigned to someone in a statement, the circumstances under which the statement applies, or the consequences that result if the statement is not followed. Altogether, these components form a syntax – or Grammar – of institutional statements along which institutions can be systematically analyzed.

RCN funds supported the formation of the Institutional Grammar Research Initiative (IGRI), a global research program convening scholars to advance IG research and application. The IGRI supports a number of ongoing initiatives:

  • A research agenda to inform ongoing innovations in IG research;

  • Monthly virtual research seminars that feature presentations from scholars using the IG; 

  • Annual virtual trainings that provide a comprehensive introduction to institutional analysis and the IG;

  • Annual in-person doctoral student workshops that offer Ph.D. students in-depth training in the IG;

  • IGRI Research Cases, one-page summaries of scholarly works that engage the IG and are intended to present research on the IG in an accessible manner;

  • IGRI Working Groups, which bring together scholars and practitioners around a shared interest related to the development and application of the IG;

  • IGRI Shorts, brief videos that provide an overview of concepts related to the Institutional Grammar in a manner accessible to non-specialists;

  • An online searchable library of English-language articles, book chapters, and review articles that address empirical applications of the IG;

  • Coding guides, software, and other tools to support scholars and practitioners using the IG.

The following metrics illustrate the growth and reach of the IGRI over the course of the RCN grant:

  • The IGRI has a network of affiliates who represent postdocs, faculty members, and practitioners who participate in IGRI activities and use the IG in research and practice. To date, the IGRI has 24 affiliates from 21 institutions in 8 countries.

  • The IGRI maintains a listserv to support communication with the broader network of scientists and practitioners working with, or interested in, the IG. To date, the listserv has 411 members.

  • IGRI research seminars average 15-20 participants.

  • The annual virtual trainings average 100 participants from 30-40 countries.

  • The IGRI has hosted three doctoral student workshops, which have averaged six students from four institutions in three countries.

  • To date, there are four active IGRI Working Groups: 

    • The Grammar of Rules-in-Use

    • The Institutional Grammar in Spanish

    • The Institutional Grammar in Chinese

    • IG-State-Reinforced Self-Governance Working GroupTo date, there are nine published IGRI Research Cases.

  • The IGRI maintains a YouTube channel and Twitter/X account, which are used to disseminate information about IGRI events as well as IGRI activities and outputs of the IGRI. The IGRI YouTube channel has 188 subscribers (with 9,438 views on 41 videos), and the IGRI Twitter/X account has 275 followers.

RCN funds have also supported the development of software and tools that  at least partially automate the application of the IG to analyze policy documents: IG Parser, IG Extract, IG Coder, and NLP4Gov.

Research performed by members of the RCN team directly contributed to the formation of a second research program called the Computational Institutional Science Lab (CISL). The mission of the CISL is to develop and apply computational tools to study how societies are governed. The CISL has a team of Lab Partners who conduct research related to the four research themes of the CISL: Theory and Concept, Computing, Software Development, and Applications. 

IGRI and CISL are independent affiliates of the Center for Policy Design and Governance at Syracuse University. Founded in 2022, the Center seeks to deepen understanding of how public policies are designed, what makes public policies effective, and how governments can support cross-sector and community engagement in the public policy process. The Center has undertaken numerous initiatives, including hosting policy design workshops and launching a Research to Practice Brief series, which involve spreading research insights gained from the RCN.


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Saba Siddiki

Research Coordination Network:


Coordinating and Advancing Analytical Approaches for Policy Design




The RCN convened an international and interdisciplinary team of scholars to study the relationship between policy design and behavior. The RCN focused on developing rigorous and reliable methods to study policy design as a basis for understanding this relationship. All policies are made up of carefully designed language that conveys who can do what, when, and how, and focal methodologies enable systematic assessment of policy language using computational and non-computational approaches.


The RCN team advanced an approach to study policy content called the Institutional Grammar (IG), where institutional refers to rules, norms, and shared strategies that govern social systems. Examples of institutions pertinent to the RCN are public policies. The IG orients an analysis of institutions on two types of institutional statements (akin to policy provisions): those regulating actions (regulative statements) and those defining systemic features (constitutive statements). The IG identifies a set of components that are common to regulative and constitutive statements, each of which are associated with specific kinds of information found in them, such as the action(s) assigned to someone in a statement, the circumstances under which the statement applies, or the consequences that result if the statement is not followed. Altogether, these components form a syntax  or Grammar  of institutional statements along which institutions can be systematically analyzed.


RCN funds supported the formation of the Institutional Grammar Research Initiative (IGRI), a global research program convening scholars to advance IG research and application. The IGRI supports a number of ongoing initiatives:




A research agenda to inform ongoing innovations in IG research;




Monthly virtual research seminars that feature presentations from scholars using the IG;




Annual virtual trainings that provide a comprehensive introduction to institutional analysis and the IG;




Annual in-person doctoral student workshops that offer Ph.D. students in-depth training in the IG;




IGRI Research Cases, one-page summaries of scholarly works that engage the IG and are intended to present research on the IG in an accessible manner;




IGRI Working Groups, which bring together scholars and practitioners around a shared interest related to the development and application of the IG;




IGRI Shorts, brief videos that provide an overview of concepts related to the Institutional Grammar in a manner accessible to non-specialists;




An online searchable library of English-language articles, book chapters, and review articles that address empirical applications of the IG;




Coding guides, software, and other tools to support scholars and practitioners using the IG.




The following metrics illustrate the growth and reach of the IGRI over the course of the RCN grant:





The IGRI has a network of affiliates who represent postdocs, faculty members, and practitioners who participate in IGRI activities and use the IG in research and practice. To date, the IGRI has 24 affiliates from 21 institutions in 8 countries.




The IGRI maintains a listserv to support communication with the broader network of scientists and practitioners working with, or interested in, the IG. To date, the listserv has 411 members.




IGRI research seminars average 15-20 participants.




The annual virtual trainings average 100 participants from 30-40 countries.




The IGRI has hosted three doctoral student workshops, which have averaged six students from four institutions in three countries.




To date, there are four active IGRI Working Groups:




The Grammar of Rules-in-Use




The Institutional Grammar in Spanish




The Institutional Grammar in Chinese




IG-State-Reinforced Self-Governance Working GroupTo date, there are nine published IGRI Research Cases.






The IGRI maintains a YouTube channel and Twitter/X account, which are used to disseminate information about IGRI events as well as IGRI activities and outputs of the IGRI. The IGRI YouTube channel has 188 subscribers (with 9,438 views on 41 videos), and the IGRI Twitter/X account has 275 followers.




RCN funds have also supported the development of software and tools that at least partially automate the application of the IG to analyze policy documents: IG Parser, IG Extract, IG Coder, and NLP4Gov.


Research performed by members of the RCN team directly contributed to the formation of a second research program called the Computational Institutional Science Lab (CISL). The mission of the CISL is to develop and apply computational tools to study how societies are governed. The CISL has a team of Lab Partners who conduct research related to the four research themes of the CISL: Theory and Concept, Computing, Software Development, and Applications.


IGRI and CISL are independent affiliates of the Center for Policy Design and Governance at Syracuse University. Founded in 2022, the Center seeks to deepen understanding of how public policies are designed, what makes public policies effective, and how governments can support cross-sector and community engagement in the public policy process. The Center has undertaken numerous initiatives, including hosting policy design workshops and launching a Research to Practice Brief series, which involve spreading research insights gained from the RCN.
